title: Decoder with Nilay Patel on TikTok

last_post.content: Thanks to @nilaypatel's interview with CEO Chris Best about Substack Notes (https://www.tiktok.com/@decoderpod/video/7221602731998498094), the company's questionable ethics are in the headlines again. Nilay points out that Substack needs to prioritize content moderation because Substack Notes are a consumer-facing social media offering. But I would argue that they were social media all along.

title: A Number System Invented by Inuit Schoolchildren Will Make Its Silicon Valley Debut

last_post.content:
“30 years ago, a group of Inuit middle school students and their teacher invented the […] “Kaktovik numerals,” named after the Alaskan village where they were created, looked utterly different from decimal system numerals and functioned differently, too. But they were uniquely suited for quick, visual arithmetic using the traditional Inuit oral counting system, and they swiftly spread throughout the region.”
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/a-number-system-invented-by-inuit-schoolchildren-will-make-its-silicon-valley-debut/

title: Substack CEO Chris Best Doesn’t Realize He’s Just Become The Nazi Bar

last_post.content:
“running a Nazi bar is not […] standing up for free speech. It’s building your own brand as the Nazi bar and abdicating your own free speech rights of association […].”
[…]
"your reputation when you refuse to moderate is not “the grand enabler of free speech.” Because it’s the internet itself that is the grand enabler of free speech. When you’re a private centralized company and you don’t deal with hateful content on your site, you’re the Nazi bar.”

https://www.techdirt.com/2023/04/14/substack-ceo-chris-best-doesnt-realize-hes-just-become-the-nazi-bar/

title: Firefox Rolls Out Total Cookie Protection By Default | The Mozilla Blog

last_post.content:
Mozilla's Firefox is walling off each site's cookies from other sites, which is helpful for privacy. I block ALL third-party cookies and use add-ons that further protect me from the increasingly evil ad-tech industry's relentless spying.

https://blog.mozilla.org/en/mozilla/firefox-rolls-out-total-cookie-protection-by-default-to-all-users-worldwide/

title: Scholastic, and a Faustian Bargain — Pretty Ok Maggie

last_post.content:
Here is a must-read post from children's author Maggie Tokuda-Hall on how Scholastic offered to distribute her book — all she had to do was remove all mention of racism.

Sure, they're banning books in Tennessee and Texas. But it's not just the books that get published and then banned from the library. It's all the books that don't get published in the first place.

Those banning books know publishers like Scholastic pull this cowardly bullshit. It's their game plan.

https://www.prettyokmaggie.com/blog/2023/4/11/scholastic-and-a-faustian-bargain

title: Upwelling: Combining real-time collaboration with version control for writers.

last_post.content:
@skyglowberlin I prefer Latex and git (or org-mode if I'm alone) + betterbibtex+Zotero. I like being able to write offline, and don't like people looking over my shoulder when I'm writing.

I'm very curious about this concept though: https://www.inkandswitch.com/upwelling/

It's a combination of git-like version control and google-docs like real time collaboration.

title: Here's why Substack's scam worked so well

last_post.content: Way back in 2021, I called out #Substack as a scam because it was masquerading as a service provider when it fact it was paying certain writers (often secretly) to create content for them. (https://buttondown.email/thehypothesis/archive/heres-why-substacks-scam-worked-so-well/) They had an editorial mission and a paid writing staff, but claimed to be a neutral service provider like Etsy for authors. Here's how that story is going ...

title: Is Substack Notes a ‘Twitter clone’? We asked CEO Chris Best

last_post.content:
This is one of the most comically disastrous social media CEO interviews I've ever read. Substack's morally vapid founders have determined that scrunching up their eyes, sticking their fingers in their ears, and yelling LALALALALA! is the ideal approach to content moderation.

The inexorable, gravitational lesson of every prior UGC platform is that a failure to have strong rules, stated clearly and enforced relentlessly, leads to a fetid swamp of toxicity.

https://www.theverge.com/23681875/substack-notes-twitter-elon-musk-content-moderation-free-speech

title: Kremlin Twitter accounts get a boost thanks to Elon Musk

last_post.content:
I wrote about why Twitter has become a national security threat, and how its owner keeps making decisions that help violent autocrats and harm democracies around the world. Currently, Musk is not only re-platforming Kremlin-linked accounts — he’s amplifying them, despite Russia’s continued involvement in war crimes and the distribution of terroristic content.
https://weaponizedspaces.substack.com/p/kremlin-twitter-accounts-get-a-boost

Real-world events the NYT might otherwise frame as "Gay People in Florida Face Increasing Harassment" or "Florida Abortion Ban Leaves Women Desperate" are now exclusively presented as "DeSantis Seeks to Rally Evangelical Voters" or "DeSantis Leans Into his Anti-Woke Brand." Once you notice it it's everywhere, and it's completely toxic.

Do you know Diplomacy, the board game for people who think they have too many friends? Skirmish Society is an asynchrone, Diplomacy-like game with a twist: it is a Discord bot. title: Column: Are you a victim of algorithmic wage discrimination? If not, just wait

last_post.content:
Ok let’s do this! For The Markup’s first #Newstodon Friday, we’re reading this piece which summarizes recent research into “algorithmic wage discrimination.” https://www.latimes.com/business/technology/story/2023-04-11/algorithmic-wage-discrimination

The finding is that gig companies are using algorithms to discover the lowest rate that people are willing to work for.

Tagging in our friends at @gbhnews @TexasObserver @damemagazine @STAT @mongabay @conversationus @thexylom and more to share a piece! #journalism #fediverse

Now that #NPR left #Twitter and many on #Mastodon are calling for it to come to the #Fediverse, maybe it's time for a recap, what we https://social.heise.de/@heiseonline did?

Our first account on mastodon.social was registered ("claimed") years ago, but left dormant until #ElonMusk bought #Twitter. Then I started to post a couple of links to #news articles every day. Our web-devs (namely @entropie) verified the account days later by adding a link to it on heise.de, giving it the green link.

Thread 🧵

last_post.content:
It's beginning to sound to me as if the US security clearance process has completely lost the plot: it focuses on whether your history can be verified and whether you can be blackmailed, not on whether you're a security risk. title: The Console That Changed Mixing Forever

last_post.content: Completely engrossed by this documentary about the first computer-controlled audio mixing console, the Solid State Logic SL 4000 E. SSL veteran Karen Down walks us through the fascinating process of setting up and using the console. I find the interface fascinating and I wonder how different it is from the original 1979 incarnation (the bootup screen text says 1995). https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KmwGACcltdQ

Using {testthat} for the first time, and goodness was I glad to have that set up when I refactored the code for the main function in a package I’m developing 😎. I’d been dragging my heels about learning to use it, in part, I think, because I thought it might be overly complicated, but it isn’t at all. {testthat} makes unit testing in #RStats a breeze and the chapters on it in R Packages (2e) ease the learning process.

https://r-pkgs.org/testing-basics.html

title: Banks say they’re acting on climate but continue to finance fossil fuel expansion

last_post.content:
Banks lent significantly less money to fossil fuel companies last year, but that decline was likely driven not by the banks' choices but because oil companies were sitting on so much cash they didn’t need to borrow any. title: Hypothesis: inflammatory acid-base disruption underpins Long Covid

last_post.content:
A mechanism for #LongCovid

I am beyond excited to finally be able to share what I’ve been working on for the past year.

At the beginning of March 22, I discovered a potential mechanism for #LongCovid. It was a unifying mechanism that could explain every single symptom that patients were reporting, something I never thought possible for a disease that has over 200. Yet, this mechanism actually did.

Link: https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fimmu.2023.1150105/full

If you care at all about the details of how GPUs do precision, conversions, rasterisation, or any of the gory fine details, then download this now.

https://microsoft.github.io/DirectX-Specs/d3d/archive/D3D11_3_FunctionalSpec.htm

This is the DX11.3 spec, and it's basically the last full one-stop-shop functional spec Microsoft ever did - those docs are now diffused across lots of web pages.

It is also used as the basis of OGL and Vulkan, and indeed all current consumer GPUs. Yes its old, but the rules haven't changed much since then.

I was just playing a game of Asteroids,¹ and I can't stop thinking about how you are moving on the surface of a torus — exiting one side of the screen (e.g., top or left) and appearing on the other side (e.g., bottom or right). That's right, you're playing on a giant SPACE DONUT!

title: Dave Winer - Developer response to Twitter cutoff

last_post.content:
Dave Winer writes about the Twitter API changes:

"Corporate platforms always fail, given enough time. The Twitter API had a good run. Now the deck is clear, and there’s room to make some new stuff, or just take a break and smell the roses a bit, or go for a bike ride. 🤪"

This seems like the right attitude to me too, even if it’s frustrating to deal with platforms failing. When one door closes, another opens.

title: The controversial article Matthew Kacsmaryk did not disclose to the Senate

last_post.content:
At the intersection of #journal #misconduct & #mifepristone restrictions.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/04/15/matthew-kacsmaryk-law-review/

Before #MatthewKacsmaryk was confirmed by the Senate as a federal judge, he removed his name from an already-submitted journal article arguing against #abortion & #trans rights. He had been listed as the sole author & recommended listing two colleagues instead. The journal agreed. The Senate requested a list of his publications & didn't know about this article before his confirmation.
